title: new-learning-hub-now-open-scottish-seabird-centre
story: The team have been working in partnership with Glasgow Science Centre for  months to transform all aspects of the five-star visitor experience and educational resources at the centre, which will reopen completely on Saturday  December followed by a formal launch in January.The learning hub will provide a more engaging and flexible space for inspiring and educating visiting schools, youth and further education groups.The new look learning hub and marine workshops are now available to book and it continues to be used by the charityrsquos weekly wildle watch groups, which are supported by the Scottish Wildle Trust.All of the furniture from the old education classroom has been given to Zero Waste Dunbar, a non-profit social enterprise which aims to keep good things in local circulation, rather than sending them to landfill.Launching the new hub, with young people from the centrersquos Wildle Watch Group, Provost, John McMillan said ldquoThe Scottish Seabird Centre has been a key part of East Lothianrsquos tourism and education offering for nearly  years. The new learning hub offers a high quality and flexible space that can be used by both East Lothian schools and residents, and those from further afield.Susan Davies, CEO of the Scottish Seabird Centre, added: ldquoScotlandrsquos marine environment is exceptional and erse. There is a growing awareness of both its importance and the pressures it is under ndash not least from the climate crisis, invasive non-native species, underwater noise and marine pollution. Our new learning hub will help us deliver on our purpose to inspire and educate people about Scotlandrsquos marine environment.Following the launch of the learning hub, the final space to be completed is the discovery experience, an interactive visitor experience which will enable people to learn more about Scotlandrsquos marine habitats and wildle, and use the interactive live cameras to watch seasonal wildle on the Firth of Forth islands. The formal launch in January will coincide with the start of Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters.

title: walk-scott-ball-raises-9000-projects
story: The lsquoScotters Ballrsquo took place at Royal Musselburgh Golf Club on November .It was hailed a huge success by the Tranent-based foundation, which said it raised about pound, for local causes and projects.Alex Hodgson and the Last Resort provided music, there was a special screening of the Walk With Scott Foundationrsquos new film about the work and history of the charity and also a raffle and an auction. Included in the auction were signed gloves by world champion boxer Josh Taylor and among the prizes were holidays and also a cooked and delivered Christmas dinner for .Karen Kidd, who helps run the foundation, said: ldquoIt was a fab night. We sold a lot of tickets to Scotters and sponsors, and everyone got dressed up and they all looked great.ldquoScott was able to attend and he even spoke for quite a while and chatted to people. It was great ndash it just means everything that he was there.ldquoWe alsohad the good news lastTuesday [November]that his son Gareth had a baby girl.

title: bay-city-rollers-star-saves-dog-stuck-hole-two-days
story: Bay City Rollers guitarist Stuart lsquoWoodyrsquo Wood was to prove the hero after Kruger, a -year-old black Labrador, went missing on Sunday, November , at about pm.Kruger was on his regular evening walk with owner Janette Murray, , of North Berwickrsquos Rhodes Park, next to the former East Lothian Council depot at Lime Grove.But after going to investigate a scent, he did notwhen called.Janettersquos daughter, -year-old Donna Denton, of the townrsquos Couper Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoHe is a rehomed dog, my mum got him when he was three.ldquoHe is quite timid but very, very friendly and doesnrsquot growl or bark at people ndash I have two kids and hersquos great with them.ldquoIf he does wander off he comes back as soon as he canrsquot see you, he always stays very close.ldquoWe now know the reason he didnrsquot come back this time. The lady from search and rescue said dogs donrsquot bark for help, only when they feel threatened.Kruger was found two days later by Bay City Rollers star Wood at about .am on Tuesday ndash the musician, who was on holiday in North Berwick, was one of  looking for the missing dog.He later posted on Facebook to say ldquothanks for the lovely messages and praising everyone who ldquosearched relentlessly.ldquoWell done everyone ndash we got lucky! he added.The terried dog was eventually found just metres from where he went missing.People all over North Berwick had helped in the search, not realising that Kruger was so close by.One man checked every bunker on the  holes at nearby Glen Golf Club ndashcounting  in total.Kruger gained access to the derelict Lime Grove site through a broken fence.Donna, a childminder and registered nurse, said: ldquoThe hole he fell down was no bigger than  centimetres by  centimetres, he couldnrsquot even lie down in it and was sitting up the whole time he was down there. We couldnrsquot even get our feet in there to help lt him out.ldquoWe phoned the fire brigade as we didnrsquot know what to do but my husband ended up putting a hoist around him and, with another manrsquos help, lting Kruger out with brute force.And she added: ldquoThe area he was found in is such a state and an absolute junkyard ndash therersquos broken bins and slabs everywhere, graffiti etc. It is not safe and is not secure.During the search, Donna contacted the police, SSPCA, search and rescue, the council and Edinburgh Dog and Cat Home, though she said she ldquocouldnrsquot get through to the dog warden at the council.After being rescued and wrapped up in blankets, Kruger was then sent to the vets for a check-up.Donna added: ldquoA man from the council had keys to the gate at the site and let me reverse my car in so I could put Kruger in the back.ldquo[Kruger] was really stf, so we had to carry him into the car and into the vets.ldquoHe was put on some fluids but my mum was able to get him home later that night luckily he wasnrsquot hurt.An appeal to find Kruger posted on social media attracted plenty of attention, something Donna was not expecting.She was full of praise for everyone who helped out, saying: ldquoEveryone was amazing. I had people I didnrsquot know come up to me at the school gates saying they were going to look for Kruger. We were just so lucky it was two mild nights when he was down there.ldquoMy mum will be  next year but was out all day trying to look for him, she didnrsquot want to stop or turn back. She was determined to find him.Since the incident, the hole has been covered with a slab, but the fence still remains damaged.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoIf anyone is aware of an uncovered manhole then itrsquos recommended that they report the exact location to the council, who will investigate further to make it safe.ldquoThis can be done online or via our out of hours number:  .

title: new-musselburgh-bar-gets-go-ahead
story: The Musselburgh Bar and Kitchen, formerly the Mexican restaurant Habaneros on High Street, was granted a iation of premises licence by East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board last week.Owner Star Pubs  Bars had applied for: extension of opening hours from midnight to am on a Thursday use of premises for clubs and group meetings an outdoor drinking area changes both internally to the building to re-position bar and seating areas and extension of the rear drinking smoking area outside.A number of objections centred around concerns of possible noise disturbance and smoke from the outdoor area.The board heard that the outdoor smoking area would be moved from its present location away from neighbouring properties and that this area would also be covered by CCTV.Members of the licensing board agreed to grant permission with conditions. They included that children and young people under  could only be on the premises after pmthey were having a meal or attending a private, pre-arranged , and that CCTV was operational both within and outside the building.In addition, the beer garden would close at pm and an entertainment licence was not granted so no recorded or live music could be played outside.The new bar had previously received planning permission.A spokesperson for Star Pubs  Bars said the premises would be turned into ldquoa modern premium bar.She said it was hoped that a new licensee would take on the venture, which would offer food throughout the day and alfresco dining.She said the proposed investment followed another recent refurbishment project involving Star Pubs  Bars at The Seaglass Inn, Port Seton, previously the Wemyss Hotel.

title: general-election-candidates-lock-horns-hustings
story: The event ndash at St Andrew Blackadder Church ndash saw the candidates answering questions submitted by the public ahead of the election next Thursday.Organised by North Berwick and District Association of Churches, it was chaired by Keith Stewart QC.Labourrsquos Martin Whitfield began by saying that serving as MP for the last two years had been a pleasure and a privilege.He also said: ldquoI am the only pro-Union person sitting on this  that can win here, which Conservative candidate Craig Hoy was quick to disagree with.David Sisson, UKIP, used a cookie jar analogy to make his partyrsquos position on Brexit clear saying: ldquoThe cookies belong to us. Itrsquos time we get them back and we can work out how we split them up once we have them back.Answering a question on how to tackle climate change Robert OrsquoRiordan, Liberal Democrats, said: ldquoI think that one of the best ways is to stay within the EU.The SNPrsquos candidate Kenny MacAskill said the country needed to disinvest in fossil fuels.The next question asked candidatesthey thought there ought to be a  per cent majority threshold on referendums.Mr MacAskill said he didnrsquot, adding: ldquoPeople werenrsquot voting for a no deal Brexit, that was never put forward. I agree that the majority prevails, but I think we have to realise thatyou win by one the winner canrsquot have all.Mr Hoy said he would agree there should be a threshold in future elections.He added: ldquoI understand why Kenny doesnrsquot support it because the SNP can barely secure  per cent, never mind  per cent, for independence.Candidates were then asked why they should be trusted by the public.Mr Sisson took this opportunity to point out that he wasnrsquot a politician and he was standing because he felt it was the right thing to do.Mr Whitfield suggested constituents believe those who did what they said they would do, adding: ldquoI think the Government breaking the law and having to be told by the Supreme Court that they have broken the law severely undermines the trust in politicians.Next, with Russia raised as a potential threat, candidates were asked about defence spending.MacAskill thought the defence budget should not change, saying: ldquoThe dficulty that faces our military is that everything is being put into nuclear weapons and Trident. I do not believe in Trident, I do not believe in nuclear weapons.Mr Sisson questioned the British Armyrsquos future as ldquoBritish defence more and more seems to be integrated into European forces.Mr Hoy said the Conservatives would increase expenditure on defence by . per cent above the rate of inflation. He added: ldquoTrident makes us safer.Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThere is a commitment from a Labour government to maintain its position in NATO and the two per cent. There is a commitment to renew Trident.Mr OrsquoRiordan also said he would maintain the two per cent GDP target, adding: ldquoIrsquom not sure of the nature of the Russian threat ndash I think it is much more to do with cyberspace and the threat to our democracy.ldquoAs we know, Boris Johnson has a dossier on his desk which he hasnrsquot released that talks about Russian intervention in the European referendum and in the European elections.Question then focused on healing the isions from Brexit, Islamophobia, and anti-Semitism in politics.Mr Hoy said he thought ldquothe issue of accountability in politics is extremely important, adding that, on comments made by Boris Johnson mocking Muslim womenrsquos appearance, he thought ldquothe Prime Minister should be held to the same account for any particular phrases that he uses but ldquothat would be for him to comment on.Mr Whitfield said he believed the Labour Party should apologise to the Jewish community for its handling of complaints of anti-Semitism in the party.He added: ldquoWith regard to what happens to bring society together widely, I think a referendum or confirmatory vote would allow people to discuss and debate and then to express their feelings through ballot box.Mr MacAskill called for better education and more enforcement, adding: ldquoYou cannot just whip up hatred and say what you like.Lastly, the candidates were asked what three things they had done for East Lothian.Mr Hoy mentioned implementing the Change and Check breast cancer campaign, voting for East Lothian Councilrsquos emergency climate change declaration, and working with police to tackle anti-social behaviour and drug use in the county.Mr Whitfield highlighted helping people with Universal Credit payments, taking county art therapy charity The Teapot Trust to Westminster and, in his previous job as a primary school teacher, teaching children in East Lothian who he had now seen getting jobs and apprenticeships.Mr OrsquoRiordan listed his involvement in setting up the hustings and working with church groups, working towards achieving the Drem-Gullane path, and convening East Lothian Liberal Democrats.Mr MacAskill cited, in his time as Justice Secretary, establishing the CashBack for Communities scheme, helping implement minimum alcohol pricing, and reducing youth offending.Mr Sisson answered by describing his work as an electrician for the council, choosing to stand as an MP, and his involvement with Musselburgh Amateur Musical Association.When asked to sing the last line of his answer by the chair, the UKIP candidate obliged, belting out to the filled church that he hoped to deliver democratic freedom to constituents.

title: bid-build-new-hotel-replace-gullanes-mallard
story: Gullanersquos The Mallard Hotel has been run by the same family for more than half a century but new plans reveal a dramatic change for the East Links Road venue.Information boards were on display in the hotel last Thursday afternoon before a presentation was given to the villagersquos community council.Currently, the hotel is made up of  bedrooms, with a bar, bistro and garden room open to the public.However, the proposed new hotel ndash which would be built over three floors ndash would include  bedrooms, as well as a restaurant, lounge and spa facilities.Structured House Group is behind the plans, with a formal planning application expected to be with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department before the end of the year.Hotel owners Cameron and Susan Law intend to step down from the business, which has been in the family for  years,the proposals are given the green light.Susan, who is also chairman of Muirfield Riding Therapy, which offers free horse-riding for people with disabilities, stressed that The Mallard Hotel remained open for business as usual and would continue to be so for the foreseeable future.She told the Courier: ldquoI think, initially, I was quite shocked that it was going to be knocked down but in retrospect it is the best thing really.ldquoObviously, we will be sad to see it go but we will take The Mallard Hotel with us is how I am thinking now. It is very dear to us.About  people attended the public exhibition in the hotel and Tony Thomas, representing the developers, was pleased with how the six-hour drop-in event had gone.He said: ldquoIt was overwhelmingly positive ndash mainly because it is not housing [being proposed].ldquoThe vast majority of people really, really like the design. The only slight hiccup was two or three immediate neighbours were concerned over parking so we will look at that. If there is not enough parking, it spills out onto the street.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, was at the presentation and the meeting afterwards.He said there were concerns about the proposals and noted residentsrsquo worries about parking and traffic generated by the new hotel.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoThe plans were well presented.ldquoWhat they are proposing is a fine installation and it looks as though it would be a good, upmarket, modern hotel with good facilities.ldquoThere is considerable concern in the community about the problems likely to arise from car parking.ldquoThat was the big issue in the discussions at the community council meeting.ldquoThere were a lot of people indicating signicant concern on that point. It is quite a heavily built-up residential area and already the parking is under pressure from residents.ldquoI would say the new hotel has signicantly more rooms than the present one. It is also supposedly going to have an upmarket restaurant, which will attract evening customers.

title: busy-a198-near-tranent-closed-several-evenings
story: There will be a full overnight closure of the A between the two roundabouts at the Bankton Junction. Drivers wanting to cross the bridge which travels over the A, linking Tranent to Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton, will face a y ersion.Joining and exiting the A at the junction will still be possible.From Monday until next Saturday , ldquoessential expansion joint replacement works will be carried out between the hours of pm and am each night.Closure of the bridge footpaths will also be required while the work is under way.Pedestrians, cyclists, and motorcycles under cc looking to cross the bridge will be marshalled safely across by the on-site team.A southbound traffic will be erted to take the first exit at the roundabout to join the A in an easterly direction towards Gladsmuir Junction.Traffic will be directed to take the exit at Gladsmuir Junction and, at the roundabout, will take the third exit onto the B.At the following roundabout, traffic will take the third exit to join the A but in a westerly direction towards Bankton Junction.From there, traffic will exit at Bankton Junction and take the second exit at the roundabout to rejoin the A.Meanwhile, A northbound traffic will be erted to take the first exit at the roundabout to join the A westbound.Traffic will proceed towards Dolphingstone and will exit at the next junction.From there, traffic will then take a right turn onto the A, crossing the A and will take a further right turn to rejoin the eastbound carriageway of the A.Traffic will follow this route to take the exit at Bankton Junction and at the roundabout will take the first exit to rejoin the A.All works are weather dependent and may be cancelled or rescheduledweather conditions are not favourable.This scheme has been planned in consultation with Transport Scotland, Traffic Scotland, the emergency services and East Lothian Council.

title: rugby-players-tackle-giant-jenners-xmas-tree
story: This yearrsquos tree is a ft-high Norway spruce that was grown in Stirling. It was supplied by Conox, which has provided Christmas trees for Edinburghrsquos Christmas market and Leicester Square in London.Ross High RFC has helped get the tree in place in Jenners for the past  years, a tradition which started after one former member had a connection to the company K which helps hoist the tree and put on the lights.John Tinlin, Ross High Rugby Club president, said: ldquoThis yearrsquos tree was not as big as it usually is but the guys all know the script.ldquoWe have to take the tree in through the revolving doors at the front of the store since there is no other way to bring it in, so we need to be very careful.ldquoThe doors are actually taken off so there is enough room. It was a tight squeeze but we managed.ldquoIt was well wrapped, which made it a lot easier.Ross High sent a team of  along to help bring the tree into the iconic Princes Street store, with the whole process taking just  minutes.John added: ldquoIt was quicker than usual.The team volunteer their time but are rewarded with pizza by the staff at Jenners.The process is a very Scottish affair, with rugby club members wearing kilts and music performed on bagpipes.Once the tree is brought in, staff from K abseil from the roof, helping to hoist it up and put the lights on ndash a process which takes place overnight.The lights were turned on by five-year-old Chloe from Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital, who won the opportunity through a charity auction.Following reports that Jenners might leave Princes Street and moving to another city centre location, John added: ldquoHopefully the tradition goes ahead again next year as we have been a part of it for such a long time.

title: grandfathers-five-decade-link-christian-aid-recognised
story: John Woodrsquos links to Christian Aid date back more than half a century and he has now been presented with a certicate to mark his commitment to the good cause.The -year-old, of Haddingtonrsquos Herdmanflatt, was taken by surprise at a recent quiz night in St Maryrsquos Parish Church for the charity, which works to support sustainable development, stop poverty and provide disaster relief.He said: ldquoI suppose after receiving the certicate I felt quite humbled about it really.ldquoIt was a surprise and I was pleased afterwards.The certicate reads: ldquoChristian Aid presents this award to John Wood in recognition of his  plus years of outstanding commitment in transforming the lives of the poor, marginalised and vulnerable.Mr Wood first got involved with the charity in the early s when he was instrumental in setting up the Haddington branch of the organisation.It has grown considerably since then, raising thousands of pounds for the international charity each year.The grandfather-of-four said: ldquoA chap from Edinburgh came out, Jimmy Hodge, who was the sole organiser of Christian Aid in Scotland at that time, and spoke about Christian Aid in the West Church.ldquoThat was the start of Christian Aid in Haddington.ldquoThe first big event was a sponsored -mile walk.ldquoAll the churches in Haddington were involved and walked to North Berwick, along the coast and back to Haddington.Since then, ious events have been organised for the charity, with the annual focus on Christian Aid Week.Members from Holy Trinity Church, St Maryrsquos Parish Church and West Church join forces for the house-to-house collection, which takes place each May.Mr Wood, who stepped down from the townrsquos Christian Aid committee earlier this year, remains involved with Holy Trinity Church, where he has been a minister for a number of years.Graham Coe, who is a member of the townrsquos Christian Aid committee, handed over the certicate to Mr Wood, who also worked with the Courier for almost  years firstly, as a compositor and then as a proof reader.Janet Chrystal, Christian Aid organiser for Haddington, said: ldquoJohn has been a mainstay in Haddington for a number of years.ldquoThe churches in Haddington have worked together for Christian Aid and we have had a joint committee and John represented Holy Trinity Church.ldquoHe stepped back at the end of August and his place has been taken by two people, which tells you his level of commitment.ldquoHe did not know he was getting the presentation, it was a surprise, but, of course, he was there as he always supports Christian Aid events.

title: santas-helping-send-north-berwick-teenager-ghana
story: Beth Poole, , who lives on Wamphray Road, left North Berwick High School in the summer.Before attending the University of Glasgow to study neuroscience, she is taking a year out to teach English and maths at a junior school in the Volta region of the West African country.She leaves next month and will be in Africa for eight months, living with a host family based within the community while she is out there.And to help fund her trip, she is organising this yearrsquos North Berwick Santa Run, which takes place next Sunday .Her African adventure is organised through Project Trust.Beth told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom really excited and nervous ndash it will be nerve-wracking at first. I am hoping it will be very rewarding. Irsquom excited to see all of the new cultures as well ndash Irsquom hoping to take some sports gear with me, Irsquove been asking some friends for their old hockey sticks.ldquoIrsquom going to teach my own class when Irsquom out there so Irsquom going on a one-week teaching course before I go.In order to go to Ghana, Beth needs to raise pound, and currently has pound, left, so has decided to host this yearrsquos Santa Run.Registration opens at .am on the day, with runs beginning at am outside the Hope Rooms ndash k, k and k runs are on offer.The route takes runners across ious parts of North Berwick, with the k heading out to Broad Sands.The routes involve water and climbing over rocky sections, so appropriate shoes and winter clothing are advised.There are some age restrictions on the runs: the k is open for all ages, with children under seven to be accompanied by an adult the k is open to those  years and over and the k for those aged  and over.Entry for under-sevens is pound, under-s pay pound and adults pound, with Scottish Athletics members receiving a pound discount.All of the money raised at the Santa Run goes towards Bethrsquos fundraising efforts.She added: ldquoItrsquos been a lot more dficult to organise than I thought but hopefully Irsquove done enough. I know itrsquos quite tough to run on the beach, but we will all be fine.Enter the run at entrycentral festival  or email bethpoole@gmailSince the run is Santa Christmas themed, participants are encouraged to wear Christmas clothing.Dogs are welcomewell behaved and on a lead.Those not taking part are welcome to spectate and support, with tea, coffee and cakes for sale in the Hope Rooms.Beach Wheelchairs, where Bethrsquos mum Cath is a volunteer, is also open and available for hire to allow everyone to take part in the event.Participants receive a Santa hat on arrival and a hot drink and home baking after completing their run.

title: Rosemary Goring  More female leaders offers hope of safer  stronger world
story: Within a decade of that declaration,   set the wheels spinning on what promises to become a century or more of exceptional chaos and carnage in the middle east, and far beyond.Everyone can get it wrong, especially those whose closely argued ideas are reduced to soundbites. And so it might yet prove with another of Fukuyamas pronouncements. It is his contention that the developed world has recently become more peaceable thanks to women as heads of state and in positions of political influence.Ive often heard people say there would be less conflict and fewer warswomen were in charge. Usually its the middle-aged and elderly ndash mothers, aunts and grandmothers ndash who make this claim. They have never scaled the heights of a male-dominated industry or profession, yet hope that the women they see in charge are imbued with the same gentle, conciliatory and nurturing personalities as themselves. And there, I would suggest, is the snag.Nor am I being unduly cynical. A study by the University of Chicago covering  years of European historyhas shown that not only were queens more inclined to take their country into battle than kings, but also more certain to win.:Nicola Sturgeon announces funding for women leaders schemeIn Victorias day, Britain was at war with some part of the empire, or would-be empire, almost every year of her reign. Three hundred years earlier, Elizabeth I set a gold standard for empire building, showing her mettle as she fought off Spanish incursions, despatching her own conquistadors across the globe, and managing to maintain stability in a precariously inflammable period of religious stre asshe were refereeing a game of croquet.The leader of the Chicago study, Professor Oeindrila Dube, points out that you need only think of Catherine the Great of Russia, or Isabella I of Castile to appreciate that, in previous centuries, royal women were every bit as war-like as men. When circumstances dictated, they didnrsquot hesitate to shed blood.Quite how they felt privately, of course, is another matter. Henry VIIIs daughter, who earned the title Bloody Mary after condemning almost  Protestants and religious dissenters to the pyre, was apparently a warm and affectionate person. What her notorious actions indicate, perhaps, is less a vengeful nature and more the vicious tenor of her times.Even our own Mary Queen of Scots was no peacenik, riding at the head of her troops on more than one occasion and, far from avoiding conflict, at times seeming actively to court it.Professor Dubersquos analysis of royal authority shows that when a queen was in power, she was even more effective than a man. Since she would often work in partnership with her consort, her subjects were effectively getting two warriors for the price of one. There is, however, a great dference between what was required of female rulers in the reign of Victoria and before, and attitudes in modern times.In almost every era prior to our own Elizabethan age, to be a woman was seen to be weak. Debate raged across Europe in the th century about how worthy and capable females could ever beplaced on a throne. John Knox, enraged at Mary of Guise becoming Regent of Scotland, spoke for many when he declared her appointment ldquoas seemly a sight as to put a saddle upon the back of an unruly cow.Given such hostility, itrsquos entirely possible that it was not the assistance of their husbands that made Boudiccas of high-ranking women, but the need to show that they were every bit as aggressive and dangerous as men. The message needed to be sent that anyone who tried to topple them would live ndash albeit briefly ndash to regret it.Margaret Thatcher thrust us into battle in the Falklands where many other prime ministers might have hesitated. You could see her pugnacity, on this and other inflammatory issues, as the problem with Fukuyamas theory. Women who reach the political pinnacle today have had to fight to get there. These are no ordinary women, these are powerful women. Hilary Clintonrsquos personality surely proves that point: her pitch for the presidency showed her to be a great deal more hawk than dove.:Project aims to help women stand for electionYet Fukuyama ndash and others ndash might nevertheless be right in hoping for a less violent futuremore women are at the top table. Nobody has done more to show Germany in a pacic and positively humanitarian light than Angela Merkel, even though she knew her policies risked her political standing in some quarters.To date, the performance of those like Mary Robinson, when she was Irish president, or Helle Thorning-Schmidt when Denmarkrsquos prime minister, or New Zealandrsquos Jacinda Ardern, not to mention Scotlands first minister, offers reason to hope. The ability to compromise, to use diplomatic means to defuse conflict, or find a way around an impasse is, while by no means solely a female quality, certainly one at which we are beginning to excel.Sweeping generalisation though it is, women are undoubtedly less physically combative and martial than men, though potentially nasty nevertheless. It can be seen as early as the school playground that our preferred weaponry is verbal attack and the ability to work stealthily, in ways of which Machiavelli would approve, to undermine the enemy.Irsquove never believed we are nicer than men ndash my experience has been quite the opposite. Yet in the West at least, attitudes in government and society are changing. Itrsquos now possible to be feminine and command respect. Gender no longer signals deficiency. Increasingly, even, it could be seen as a positive advantage.Growing numbers of women are rising through the democratic ranks on the strength of their strategic and negotiating skills, rather than their gung-ho, macho credentials. As a new generation is attracted to these roles, seeing that they no longer need to act tough in order to succeed, then things might just improve. Perhaps it is a reasonable assumption after all that, with more female hands at the tiller, nations will become stronger and safer.

title: fidelma-cook-saw-poverty-shocked-core-glasgow-1970s-worse
story: My worst fear is a Tory majority which will almost certainly herald a No Deal BrexitJohnson sticks to his no extension pledge when even he is unable to magic the withdrawal agreement into a trade deal within his timescale.My best hope, a hung Parliament, there to nip his ankles and stymie in part the madness that is bound to unfold.Like many of you Brexit has become a background to daily le, as has did the run up to the election. Little  penetrated for those of us consumed by its ramications.Those of us living in one of the many other countries in the European Union who have even more,that were possible, to fear, in every restriction on Freedom of Movement and right to services.Public debate and opinion have been coarsened and vulgarised these past three years, and thrashing around for scapegoats, the thugs and the bigots given licence to spew hot, ugly words.When parliamentarians lie, cheat and choose not their words wisely, then why should some of the public Suddenly, festering resentment has been allowed free and open expression and it is ugly shameful unworthy of a people who like to think themselves above all others.As merely a watcher ndash although consumed by anger with much I see ndash even I feel burned out.It took a television programme to remind me that to millions, yes millions, such self-indulgent anorakism has no place in their daily thoughts.Channel rsquos Dispatches: Growing Up Poor: Britainrsquos Breadline Kids punched through all mental meanderings and abstract anger with facts revealed without comment or rising faux hysteria.Four point one million children grow up in poverty. One in three of British children. Repeat thathellip. in .They mainly rely on food banks as their parents, usually a lone mother, have been failed by a rigged system presided over by the DWP, whose officers work without compassion or understanding but to a set of rules cheered in by the Tory Party.Universal Credit is a system evolved out of austerity measures introduced by David Cameronrsquos government. In material terms the austerity programme has been responsible for rising food prices and financial insecurity.Food banks and their usage have soared and under the current government a further one million children are expected to slip into poverty over the next four years.There are now an estimated , food banks distributed across the UK. They have become an acceptable skein in the fabric of le ndash replacing the workhouse of old just keeping heads above water.One of the first rules in tabloid journalism is to personalise a story. If readers can see a face, hear an inidualrsquos words while searching a face, it becomes real. Mere facts, however shocking, are never enough.Out of the three families featured in the documentary, one stood out for me. Courtney, aged eight, lived with her mother and five-year-old brother after domestic abuse forced them out of the house.The mother is often not well ndash mental health issues ndash and because of a hold up in DWP payments they were living on the childrenrsquos benefits of pound a day.That meant food or heat or a five-mile walking round-trip to the food bank. Courtney, a pretty imp of a child with an already sage intelligence, sang and skipped as the heavy bags dragged on her arms as the three made the trip home.With her ever vigilant concern and watchful eyes on her mother and brother, Courtney is classed as part of another lsquonewrsquo movement. She is one of around , young careers who should be carefree not caring.God knows in my first few years working in Glasgow in the mid-s I saw poverty that shocked me to the core. Ghettoised poverty confined to certain areas in cities.But this poverty is somehow dferent. Itrsquos a widespread almost fact of le.Children do manage to eat, one way or another, there is a roof over their heads but, and this for me is the killer, hope has been denied.This lsquopovertyrsquo is deemed acceptable just a part of le a shrugged lsquothatrsquos how it is.rsquoMeanwhile billions, billions are lsquospaffedrsquo as Johnson would say, on a futile, fruitless show of imperial power by men and women who have never known raw, gut-wrenching hunger or faced a choice between sleeping three to a bed in overcoats or using enough fuel credit to fill a hot water bottle.This is what our minds and our rage should be addressing every day. Not this side-show of ultimate impotence whichever way the result goes.That children in  in still one of the worldrsquos richest countries should be living like this is a disgrace. The poor do not always have to be lsquowith usrsquohellip.neither do heartless politicians.

title: hugely-interesting---ron-mackennas-verdict-paesanos-little-sister-sugo-pasta-glasgow
story: Mitchell Street, GlasgowHAVE you ordered, the waitress says as she walks right up to me. Uh  This is a very surprising question considering we can both see she is holding in her actual hands, so close that I can savour their deliciousness, the two actual pasta dishes that I actually, er, ordered.ldquoEr, yes, I say. And suddenly. Without a word. She turns and leaves. Taking my pasta away. Back deep into the bowels of this staggeringly huge restaurant which tonight, a Wednesday, is absolutely heaving, jumping, packed-full, people talking, eating, gesturing, some still waiting at the door, queueing. Pastas being forked, flipped, slurped, dripped, even dropped while mine is leaving on a bloody jet plane. Donrsquot know when it will be back again.ldquoWTF Irsquom in the middle of saying to absolutely nobody because tonight, Matthew, Irsquom eating all alone. At a tiny leper table near the entrance.Then another waitress spots my speech bubble and chases the first one down. A discussion takes placehellipthe pasta still inching stubbornly towards that massive open kitchen so far away, so obscured by standing, sitting, yapping, eating humanity that not once tonight will I get a clear view of it.Hang on, the pastas are swinging back again. Returning. Bobbing, weaving, arriving in a crash landing before me, no explanation, or apology from the first waitress. A wry smile from the second. Sigh.As a result of this mad episode Irsquom going to have to order another pasta later because one thing about pasta that is an absolute fact  It needs to be piping hot when it gets to the table. Steam rising, sauces still sliding, slithering and slipping into shape. And this definitely ainrsquot.Still, Sugo here is the searingly hottest ticket in town. The owners of the undoubtedly brilliantly successful Paesano restaurants trying to do that impeccably-sourced, authentically made and astonishingly cheap thing they did with pizza to pasta.Crikey, fresh hand-made pasta  On this scale: Revolutionary. They donrsquot even eat that in Italy. Only kidding, though outside the home itrsquos nowhere near as available as you would think. For good reasons, not least that the dried stuff is pretty great anyway, and not nearly as risky to handle.What is it like then  Honestly  A hit and a good few misses. Little origami parcels of agnolotti, stuffed with nicely balanced veal, potato and cavallo nero, draped in salty buttery thyme  Pleasant, reasonably good pasta.Then a Jamie Oliver-esque bowl-shaped dome of fine-ish tagliarini, all speckled with reds and green, crumbled with pangratto, pretty, hot with chilli and sold at an almost unbelievable fiver  Hmm. Dry, utterly tasteless, a little sticky in parts and disappointing but also fabulously meaty, superbly deep ragu, chunks of unctuous beef, the pappardelle pasta folded like ribbons of silk, probably the most suitable for serving freshly-made of the dishes Irsquoll have tonight. Itrsquos very good, though a few strands are stuck together. But this I would definitely have again.Now, Irsquod heard they have a problem with portion sizes in here. And I think they already know that. The waitress certainly told me right off that servings are  grams, so maybe three plates for two people. Strange.Surprising, then, to see that  grams on the plate looks like itrsquos way more than enough. A big portion but in the same way pasta doesnrsquot hold its heat like pizza, pasta doesnrsquot fill like pizza. And I find I can easily handle another dish just to see what itrsquos like when served piping hot.The spaghetti, then, with clams and white wine. Theyrsquore good at the sauces in here, definitely, but that springy, bouncy, under this light yellowy, curly spaghetti  That looks like the awful stuff they sell in bags in supermarkets. I donrsquot warm to it. At all. Dried pasta, at Molisana say, would have been better.Despite all this: what Sugo are trying is actually, genuinely, pretty revolutionary. Some of it I think they have got wrong but maybe enough of the whole package they have got right.Sugo Pasta Mitchell StreetGlasgowNo bookingsMenu: Itrsquos pasta but not as you know it ndash all freshly made this very day and thatrsquos a pretty revolutionary and hugely interesting idea.  Service: Itrsquos all a bit bish-bosh, tables being shouted, people being shunted and I had a very odd experience, probably because I was eating alone and ordered two dishes.  Atmosphere: Absolutely bursting with the excitement and anticipation of the moment and all the more fun to be there. Great vibe.  Price: Just like their Paesano pizza restaurants the secret weapon is the fabulously clever pricing with a bowl of tagliarini from just a fiver, and most dishes under a tenner.  Food: Great concept, very good sauces, the fresh pastas are a hit or a miss and possibly need an overall rethink but as this is a brave, new world, I hope they succeed.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: AS our politicians grub for votes, Unspun hears some punters are taking it upon themselves to raise the tone of the national debate. Like the one who interrupted STVrsquos constituency profile of Glasgow North East. As the camera started rolling, a passerby immediately dropped his trousers and pants and began leaping about shouting ldquohairy hairy monkey downthe lens. These things happen in Possil. Sadly, however, this inspirational act of public indecency will never be broadcast on taste grounds. ldquoIt was also a cold day, so not very much to see, reports our mole.Political animalTHE LibDems are doing their best inRoss, Skye and Lochaberto oust top Nat Ian Blackford. Rather awkwardly, the seatrsquos  LibDem candidate, Jean Davis, this week backed the SNP. Mr Blackford was jubilant. However, Ms Davis had previously declared her dog would help decide her vote by wiping one of the candidates names off her tiled floor. So perhaps not the most stellar of endorsements. Now a cat...Ladies onlyRAISED eyebrows too at the SNPrsquos launch of a ldquomini-manesto of key pledges for women, presumably to avoid the poor dears tiring their wee brains and burning the dinner. ldquoWhatrsquos next  wonders our unimpressed source. ldquoA free lippy and mirror with every vote  One gal who obviously needs no support is Jo Swinson. Her latest leaflet in East Dunbartonshire claims she has helped with ldquoalmost , issues. Who knew there even were , issues to get fussed about  No doubt therersquos a bar chart to explain it all.Long-le LeonardMIND -blowing statistic of the week: Richard Leonard has been leader of Scottish Labour longer than Kezia Dugdale. Mr Leonard passed his predecessorrsquos  days on Wednesday, his anonymity unscathed. Ms Dugdale quit after going backwards at two elections. Having lost both his MEPs in May, Mr Leonard now looks set to lose more MPs next week. Will he follow suit  Holyrood wags sayhe does, therersquos a jungle-based TV talent show thatrsquoll snap him up: Irsquom a Non-entity Get Me Out of Here.Wings not over ScotlandSO, farewell then, to the Sturbocopter. A prominent part of general elections past, the SNPrsquos Sturgeon-themed helicopter has been grounded and the First Minister has taken to a Nattle Bus instead. Besides bad weather and looking elitist, the whirlybird also cost SNP HQ a ton of dosh in  and , so itrsquos no wonder its gone. As new data showed on Thursday, the party has reported just pound, in non-bequest private donations during the campaign.Lots of ShottsTOUGH times for the SNPrsquos Neil Gray in Airdrie  Shotts by the look of a desperate email he sent this week pleading for help with ldquo, letters that need to be stuffed and sorted as quickly as possible before polling day. ldquoIt is a huge task, Mr Gray wailed. ldquoPlease come alongyou can to help at this crucial part of the campaign. Despite Jeremy Corbynrsquos best efforts, it seems his -vote majority over Labour is looking rather vulnerable.Get a load of youCAN you have too much democracy in an election  Scotlandrsquos poundm talking shop, the Citizens Assembly, thinks so. Its monthly blethers would usually have the online world agog. But it recently cancelled its live-stream to an expectant nation to avoid ldquosuggestions that we are drawing attention away from or otherwise intervening in the General Election. We have not taken this decision lightly. Draw attention away from the election  Such modesty!

title: kevin-mckenna-scotland-not-better-england-just-different---thank-goodness
story: During the first independence referendum Unionists were often accused of lying when they ascribed a worst-case scenario to economic forecasts or when they spoke darkly of civil unrest on Scotlandrsquos streets when there had only been loud heckling. Few of us,we were being honest, really believed these were lies exaggeration: perhaps grandstanding: definitely, but not a deliberate attempt to swap a known hood for a universally-accepted fact.As the  General Election campaign enters its final week it is now routinely described by commentators and politicians alike as "rancorous", "unpleasant" and "bitter". In truth, though, itrsquos not really been much more obnoxious than most others in our letimes. Social media tends to amply prickliness and makes it monstrous. That which we once considered only to be disagreeable now becomes disgusting. Perhaps this is what happens when thousands of us now find we can take to the stage and think that only by shouting the loudest can our voices be heard in a crowded market-place.What has made this election unique in my letime is how simplistic to an almost insulting degree has been the offering of the UK Government. When the optimistic investment numbers and shaky NHS promises are stripped away it comes down to one slogan: Get Brexit Done.This flies on the deception that our withdrawal from the EU can be wrapped up before the Christmas trees come down and that everything will be back to normal before next summer. It omits to provide the truth of the two yearsof tough negotiations with a sullen EU on future trading arrangements conducted on a painstaking case-by-case, sector-by-sector basis. It asks us to accept that the US will be falling over itself to be charitable in cutting a beneficent trade deal. It long ago ceased even trying to deny predictions of economic hardship in Britainrsquos most disadvantaged communities. It dismisses concerns that any part of the NHS will be on the table when the Americans come knocking. Aye, right! These may not be outright lies but they rely on concealing all relevant data to those who are most at risk from its adverse effects.If it prevails on December  the duplicitous and infantile nature of Boris Johnsonrsquos personal manesto will make the isions between Scotland and England deeper than they have ever been. Even in this age when we are too ready to reach for extremes and ultimates the dferences have become a chasm. By the time this one is over six elections will have been conducted in Scotland since , encompassing Holyrood, Westminster, local authorities and the European Parliament. The previous five have all ed resounding victories for the SNP campaigning for self-determination and, latterly, a second referendum on independence. This one will follow that pattern. Wersquove also had a referendum on membership of the EU which overwhelmingly rejected what Englandrsquos heart desires. This though, only hints at the cultural, philosophical and political chasm which now exists between Scotland and our great southern neighbours across more sectors than we could ever have previously imagined.This is not to say that Scotland is better than England or that we hold ourselves to a higher moral standard merely that the governments either country has chosen to represent its peoplersquos aspirations regard humanity and human existence in starkly dferent ways. In Scotland our political instincts and legislation is geared towards providing options for the poor, the vulnerable, the excluded and those fleeing terror in other countries. In England, the Boris Johnson optionis to gain power at any cost and to hold it with every artice at his disposal. It discourages speaking truth to power but submerges truth with power.It relies on the confidence that comes with knowing that the main mass media outlets are strictly controlled by a handful of those whose best material interests are served by him or who attended the same school as him. He knows that no-one will look under the bonnet or ask for his workings. It constructs  enemies at home and abroad and stitches them up as the culprits for ills both real and imagined. As the challenges of Brexit begin to bite in those communities least equipped to deal with them the EU is already in the crosshairs of the backlash when it comes.In Scotland there can be valid criticism of the Scottish Governmentrsquos stewardship of the NHS and education but there are key dferences of attitude in these landscapes. In Scotland we want them to deliver for as many as possible and with no exceptions and the failures are of management and civil service incompetence. In Boris Johnsonrsquos England health is being set up to fail and thus to attract the predators of private equity.The great and humane system of care as devised by a great Welshman in England can now only be seen in Scotland. Here, a child has access to  hours of early learning and nursery care, saving families more than pound. In Scotland our students are provided with free tuition while those in England must find almost pound, a year. Prescriptions and care for the elderly are free. In Scotland we want to make the journey from the cradle to the grave as long and as comfortable as possible. In England in the grip of the Johnson regime the same journey will become shorter and more brutal as Brexit and Americarsquos big pharmaceutical companies gather to feed.By all means letrsquos get Brexit donethat is what England truly desires but let it soon be followed by Scottish independencewe truly desire decency and compassion.

title: peter-pan-house-one-worlds-coolest-places
story: Moat Brae, where author JM Barrie played as a child, has long been credited as the place where he gained the inspiration to write the timeless childrenrsquos classic.Now the Georgian property has been named as one of the ldquocoolest places in the world to visit by Time magazine following its multi-million reinvention as Scotlandrsquos new National Centre for Storytelling and Childrenrsquos Literature.The house, in Dumfries, was selected as one of the  sites around the globe children must see.The building was saved from demolition a decade ago and has now been restored as an international visitor attraction.A campaign by the Peter Pan Moat Brae Trustto raise pound million for the renovation was spearheaded by actress and trust patron Joanna Lumley, and the house, which opened in the summer, now features on Timersquos Worldrsquos Coolest Places list for .The magazine said it had based its selections on ldquoquality, originality, sustainability, and accessibility.Describing Moat Brae, it said: ldquoIn , Moat Brae reopened as Scotlandrsquos National Centre for Childrenrsquos Literature and Storytelling.ldquoKids can run through the buildingrsquos enchanted gardens, enjoy the Lost Boysrsquo tree house and board a full-scale pirate ship. Indoors, they can search for hidden messages scattered around the house or look for Peter Panrsquos shadow.Staff member Catherine Colwell told the magazine: ldquoMoat Brae is a very special place. It gives anyone, no matter their age, the freedom to explore their own imagination.JM Barrie, was born in Kirriemuir, Angus, in , but moved to Dumfries aged  after the death of his older brother David, in an ice-skating accident.Barrie became friends with Stewart and Hal Gordon, whose father owned Moat Brae, and spent a great deal of time in their company there.He credited the hours he spent playing in its gardens for firing his imagination, eventually leading to the creation of Peter Pan and all his adventures.The author wrote: ldquoWhen shades of night began to fall, certain young mathematicians shed their triangles, crept up walls and down trees, and became pirates in a sort of Odyssey that was long afterwards to become the play of Peter Pan. For our escapades in a certain Dumfries garden, which is enchanted land to me, were certainly the genesis of that nefarious work, Peter Pan.Peter Pan began as a play before being turned into a novel and has gone on to become a firm favourite which children and adults like, as well as spawning several cartoons and films.It is hoped that more than , people a year will visit the attraction, with the centre potentially boosting the local economy by pound.m a year.The centre is home to the original ldquoTinker Bell ndash a small bell JM Barrie bought to be rung when the fairy character appeared on stage in the original production of the story ndash and a dollsrsquo house which is nearly ft tall.Other attractions featured on Timersquos list included the new Star Wars attraction at Disney World in Orlando, Florida, Niagara Falls, the Statue of Liberty Museum in New York and Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris.Simon Davidson, Moat Braersquos centre director, said: ldquoWe are obviously delighted and flattered to be part of Timersquos Top  Coolest Places for Kids and to be in such esteemed company.ldquoReading down the list you see Mission Control, Houston, Notre Dame, Paris, Statue of Liberty, New York, and then Moat Brae, Dumfries, Scotland, UK.ldquoMoat Brae opened in June  to celebrate the lsquoenchanted landrsquo that inspired the writer of Peter Pan.ldquoOne of our key objectives was create an attraction for Dumfries that people from all over the world would want to come to learn about our phenomenal history and to be inspired to find the creative spark within themselves.ldquoReceiving this kind of recognition is a huge endorsement.

title: estates-can-save-planet-peatland-projects-get-way
story: The Precious Places drive aims to highlight the environmental, social and economic benefits delivered all year round by moorland managers. Grouse moors act as huge carbon stores and pro-active management practices help support active peat bogs rich in wildle.More than  per cent of Scotland is covered in peatland, areas of moor that could hold the key to halting climate change due to their unmatched abilityto lock greenhouse gases deep within the soil.The carbon-storing properties of healthy and well-managed peatlands are renowned, as well as being important wildle habitat, being home to rare birds, mammals and plant species.Peat marshes also help improve water quality and play a vital part in reducing flood risk.Estates across the Tomatin, Speyside, Grampian, Loch Ness and Southern Upland areas have been leading the charge to repair degraded peatlands to enhance their carbon storage capacity.Estates undertaking peatland restoration projects include The Hopes Estate in the Lammermuir Hills, Alvie and Pitmain on Speyside. There has also been extensive peatland restoration completed on Garrogie and Corriegarth estates near Inverness.Projects have also taken place on Farr and Glenmazeran in the Monadhliath Mountains. Estates that are part of the Grampian Moorland Group that have undertaken peatland restoration projects include Invercauld and Candacraig, as well as Mar Lodge and Glenfeshie in the Cairngorms.Spanning , hectares, most of which is open hill and moorland, The Hopes has been heavily involved in intensive peatland restoration activity, working with the Scottish Government through the Scottish Natural HeritagePeatland Action Fund.The project was to restore the peatland on two previously unmanaged sites, covering an estimated  hectares.This has enabled the regeneration of large areas of blanket bog, rich in the main peat-forming species, sphagnum moss.This peatland restoration will ultimately allow for higher levels of carbon capture. Robbie Douglas Miller, owner of The Hopes, said: ldquoWe wholeheartedly support the Precious Places campaign, as moors play a crucial role in all our lives by providing multiple benefits for people and nature. When healthy, they lock in carbon to help combat climate-change, support bioersity and safeguard rural jobs.ldquoI see estate owners, managers and gamekeepers as custodians of that space. We are committed to carrying out vital conservation work across Scotlandrsquos moorlands by implementing climate change measures to help preserve important moorland habitats and save our beautul Scottish landscape for generations to come ndash this will only be achieved by pro-active management.Lianne MacLennan, coordinator of the Grampian Moorland Group, said: ldquoScotlandrsquos grouse moors are special and precious. Degraded peatland was mapped in the Cairngorms National Park and two sites at Invercauld were estimated to be emitting a total of , tons of carbon dioxide equivalent a year.ldquoOnce the peatland restoration work is complete it will make a huge contribution to the overall level of carbon capture across Scotlandrsquos grouse moors.Out of Scotlandrsquos . million hectares of peatland about , hectares show evidence of erosion.The restoration of , hectares of degraded peatland areas by  is one of the objectives of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Climate Change Plan is hoping to achieve.Dee Ward, owner of Rottal Estate in Angus, has completed a tree planting project and is due to undertake a major peatland restoration project in spring .He said: ldquoWe have planted over  acres here at Rottal Estate, totalling , trees, mainly native broadleaves and Scots pine. By doing this we hope to deliver carbon capture, flood mitigation, and bioersity.ldquoWe work closely with the RSPB and we strive to maintain a balance so that we have specic habitats for waders, moorland for black and red grouse, and woodland areas.ldquoNext year there will also be a major peatland restoration project here, covering about  hectares.Since , over , hectares of degraded peatland have been put on the road to recovery with funding provided by the Scottish Government through the Scottish Natural Heritage Peatland Action Fund.

title: kate-bush-scholarly-spotlight-art-college-stages-symposium
story: Since making her debut with her first single Wuthering Heights back in , she has also been labelled an eccentric and a recluse.She has also been popular with female impressionists who love making fun of her early vocal style.But now Kate Bush has become the subject of academic study. A two-day symposium on the artist titled This Womanrsquos Work will take place at the Edinburgh College of Artin the capital next Thursday and Friday.Academics will be presenting papers to an audience of fellow academics and fans on topics ranging from gender subversion to folk horror in the Bushrsquos work.ldquoItrsquos not your stereotypical dry academic conference, said Dr Johnny Murray, one of the eventrsquos organisers. Bushrsquos biographerGraeme Thomson is also attending, as is photographer Max Browne who shot her  tour.Mr Murray, who is senior lecturer in film and visual culture at ECA, has put the symposium together with his colleague Dr Glyn Davis. They have previously arranged symposiums on the Pet Shop Boys and Grace Jones.The reason they have chosen to focus on Bush, he explained, is because she is ldquocompletely unique.He added: ldquoShe is incredibly curious, intellectually speaking. A lot of her work takes reference from other art forms. Wuthering Heights would be a great example of that.ldquoThroughout her career shersquos been influenced by literature, shersquos been influenced by cinema, shersquos been very powerfully influenced by dance and modern choreography. The only two tours shersquos done to date are both incredibly theatrical performance art-based works in and of themselves.ldquoThere are so many dferent facets to her. In technological terms and gender-based terms she has been a pioneer ndash one of the first women to take control of her career in the sense of taking a lead production role on her records.ldquoApart from the quality and complexity of the songwriting on albums like The Dreaming, The Hounds of Love and The Sensual World, just how she was using the recording studio at that time is a real inspiration.ldquoThose albums still remain a landmark in terms of how you use new technology to create particular kinds of sounds, he added.:Herald Diary -Kate Bush on the binsIf anything, he believes, her long absence from public view after the birth of her son Albert in  only increased the publicrsquos interest in her. ldquoPopular interest and celebration of her and her achievements has, in my mind, only intensied over the years since she came back with [album] Aerial in .ldquoShersquos been such an innovative and non-conformist artist. Itrsquos very rare ndash David Bowie, I suppose, would be one of the other examples ndash to think of someone whose cultural influence and profile has been sustained over the decades but intensies during the later period of their career. Shersquos the antithesis of that old cliche, lsquoWe prefer her early work.rsquoAmong those speaking at the symposium is Samuel Love who has just graduated from ECA with a Masters by Research in History of Art. His paper, How Beautul It Is, Amongst All the Rubbish, will discuss the notion of Englishness in Kate Bushrsquos work.ldquoThe first thing people would associate with Kate Bushrsquos Englishness would probably be her reputation for eccentricity, Mr Love says. ldquoI couldnrsquot think of too many other national cultures that would give us something like Wuthering Heights as a breakout single.ldquoPersonally, though, I think the most important aspect of her Englishness runs deeper and has to do with the omnipresent nature of the countryside, standing in as a semi-magical and totally prelapsarian space of fantasy and innocence, in her music.:Review -Six Plays Inspired by the Songs of Kate Bush,ldquoI think that sense of spiritual reverence for place has a long history in English art and is one of the most prominent ways in which England is mythologised as a site of folklore and mysticism ndash itrsquos right there in the pagan woodland in Hounds of Love, the sequestered garden of Under the Ivy and the living, breathing country of Oh England, my Lionheart.The symposium will open on the same day as the General Election. ldquoWe will be having lsquoVote Katersquo badges made for all delegates, Mr Murray revealed. ldquoRegardless of political affiliations and disagreements we will all be presenting a united front with our lapel badges.A Kate Bush Symposium takes place at ECA, December -. Visit www.eca.ed.ac.uk event womans-work-kate-bush- symposium

title: scotland-lagging-broadband-services
story: According to the analysis, of  areas in the UK with the worst mobile and broadband service,  were in Scotland ndash amounting to around half of all the parliamentary constituencies in the country.Camleys Cartoon: Superfast broadband delayed.The study, which covered all  constituencies across the UK, found that the four worst areas for mobile coverage are all in Scotland.Five of the  areas with the poorest broadband service are also in Scotland. The consumer group Which  has now called on the government to introduce connectivity target-driven action to improve ldquoinadequate mobile and internet connections, as their research also revealed people in more than one in three UK constituencies do not have access to decent G or broadband services.It recommends removing barriers to speedy and effective broadband roll-out programmes, including a legal requirement for new-build homes to be built with gigabit-capable connections.The research comes after it emerged that the SNPrsquos flagship pound million pledge to bring superfast broadband to every home and office in the country could be delivered three years late.Na h-Eileanan an Iarcame bottom of the Which  mobile coverage table as they had just . per cent of premises with G access. Caithness, Sutherland  Easter Ross had the second worst service at .%, followed by Ross, Skye and Lochaberand Orkney  Shetland .Orkney  Shetland had the worst broadband service in the UK, with just three in four premises with access to Ofcomrsquos definition of a decent connection ndash a download speed of at least mpbs with mbps upload.Ross, Skye  Lochaber had the second worst broadband quality with one in eight unable to access a decent connection while Na h-Eileanan an Iar was found to have the third worst service as .% can obtain decent speeds.Caroline Normand, Which  director of advocacy, said: ldquoFor far too long, people have felt cut off and struggled to pay bills or receive important calls and messages because of poor mobile and broadband connections.ldquoThe next government must finally deliver the strategy needed to connect the whole of the UK with the comprehensive digital infrastructure that communities urgently need while ensuring that consumers have a choice of providers so that they can see real improvements.In evidence to Holyroodrsquos Rural Economy and Connectivity Committee in April, Ofcomrsquos chief technology officer, Mansoor Han, admitted that meeting targets for mobile coverage would be dficult.Mobile companies were expected to provide % of geographical coverage by  but this target poses specic challenges in Scotland, according to Mr Han.While it has been proposed to set a target of % for mobile coverage across Scotland, Mr Han said that the geography of Scotlandrsquos mountainous areas makes this dficult with existing technology.Broadband has become a key issue in this election, with the main parties competing over who can produce the most eye-catching plan to entice voters.The Conservatives have pledged an investment of pound billion to cover the whole of the UK with ldquogigabit-capable broadband services by .They have also promised to finalise a poundbn agreement with mobile phone operators to build newphone masts to improve mobile services in hard-to-reach areas and has committed to spending poundbn on broadband and to helping to reach the most remote areas.Meanwhile, Labour have set out a broadband pledge to nationalise BTrsquos Openreach ision, invest pound.bn in getting ldquofull fibre to everyoneby  and giving everyone free broadband.The Liberal Democrats have promised to invest in mobile data infrastructure and expand it to cover all homes and install hyper-fast, fibre-optic broadband across the UK.The SNP has called for more investment from Westminster and a ldquoshared rural network to deliver % G mobile coverage in Scotland.Which  said that while broadband is playing a pivotal role in the General Election, a ldquohuge leap is needed to improve connectivity as a whole.ldquoThe next government must ensure that mobile coverage is brought up to the level consumers deserve, the consumer organisation said.ldquoWithout an overarching vision for both fixed and mobile services shared by government, Ofcom and industry, and a cohesive strategy in which roles, responsibilities and timescales are clearly defined, many people will still risk losing out on the benefits of good quality connections.It said it wanted an ldquoambitious, joined-up strategy to deliver improved digital infrastructure, ldquomeeting the needs of people to be connected at home, at work and on the move.

title: mother-whose-partner-took-life-launches-campaign-kindness-christmas
story: Karen McKeown, from Wishaw, has urged Scots to look out for their loved ones over the festive period due to the issues accessing mental health services and the mental dficulties that the period can bring.The mother-of-two has been fighting to get justice for her partner Luke Henderson since his death on December , , after he repeatedly requested help from the NHS but was turned away several times.As highlighted by the Herald on Sunday, Ms McKeown visited eight medical facilities and spoke to almost a dozen members of staff in the week before her partners death in a desperate attempt to get help for him.Despite her efforts, doctors told her that her partner was not suicidal, had no apparent mental health dficulties and that he would not be able to receive any medication to help him.Prior to contacting health services, Mr Henderson had been having delusions and had been awake for days on end, frequently leaving the house and ing hours later, covered in sweat and unable to articulate where he had been or what he was thinking.Medics eventually referred Mr Henderson to addiction services, where the couple were told to fill in a form and then sent away.He took his own le in the home that he shared with Ms McKeown and their two children just four days after Christmas.Ms McKeown said: "Christmas time is really dficult for people who have mental health problems, and it can be dficult for those who have lost loved ones too. While everyone is going about their business, trying to get into the festive spirit and have a nice time, it can make others feel even worse."Ms McKeown wants to encourage people to look out for their friends and family during the Christmas season, when, she says, it is easier to allow mental health dficulties to become too much to handle.It is also a period where traditionally many specialist services would be closed or have reduced hours, making it harder to access the type of help needed.She also launched a government petition last year calling for a review of all suicides where the person had recent interaction with mental health services prior to their death.Last month the Holyrood petitions committee closed her appeal as they said the issues were already forming part of their current strategy.Although disappointed, Ms Mckeown said she was undeterred and will continue fighting for better mental health care in Scotland.She said: "I am disappointed about the fact they closed my petition but its not the end of the campaign. Thats why I want to keep reminding people they can talk about their mental health, and Christmas is one of the times I think it will be especially important."Over Christmas it can be really dficult and we just want people to get in touch with their friends and relatives, check in on them and asktheyre okay."Its a time for celebrating but it can be hardpeople are mentally ill and they dont always feel like seeing people. Thats why its so important to check in on them ndashyouve not heard from them for a few days, just askthey are alright."People also have to be able to ask the questionthey are really concerned about someone, they need to be able to ask themthey are suicidal."Its a very dficult thing to do, but it can save a le, so people have to be able to ask the dficult thingsthey are concerned."

title: glasgow-council-equal-pay-claim-firm-action-4-equality-scotland-suspends-activities
story: Action  EqualityScotland said it had received a letter from the Financial Conduct Authoritystating it did not comply with new legislation.The organisation was informed that itsclaims management activities breached the legislation, which AES stated it was"completely unaware of".Director Stefan Cross said: "AES was completely unaware of the fact that legislation had been brought into effect in Scotland from April ."As a result, it was decided to suspend all of AESs activities whilst these matters are investigated."Action  Equality Scotland represented the majority of the, mainly female workers who secured a settlement ofpound million from Glasgows local authority.:Money deducted from Glasgow city council equal pay fight claimants to cover union legal feesIt follows an investigation by the BBC showed thousands of women who fought for equal pay last year had money deducted from their compensation packets to cover legal fees.The company agreed a .% contribution would be taken from each of the , women represented in the dispute with the council.In a statement to the press, director Stefan Cross QC added: "It is very regrettable that this situation has occurred and Id like to personally apologise to the womeninvolved."However Ican assure them that we have taken allnecessarysteps to ensure thattheirclaims can proceed normally.Claims management companies in Scotland have
